coredata.dc:title: Reversing nitride/fluoride distribution in the solid electrolyte interphase enables a highly reversible lithium metal anode

coredata.dc:description: A robust solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is essential for constructing high-performance lithium-metal battery (LMB). Here, we designed a unique layered SEI film with a reverse gradient distribution of nitride and fluoride compounds using a dual-salt electrolyte. Notably, the solvation structures, especially aggregates (AGG) are influenced by both the concentration effect and the binding energy differences between different anions and lithium ions. Through finely adjusting AGG, the anion decomposition processes can be controlled, thereby optimizing the component ratio of SEI film. As a result, the optimized electrolyte achieves a high CE of 99.50 % and ensures dendrite-free lithium deposition. The LMB (50 μm Li|| LiFePO4, N/P ratio is 3) achieves high capacity retention rate of 90 % after 300 cycles. This work not only develops a novel and excellent electrolyte for stable LMBs, but also reveals the internal mechanisms between solvation structure and SEI component/structure.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: SEI structure design and feasibility analysis for lithium metal batteries. The SEI models with different structure, including mosaic model (a), inner fluoride/outer nitride (b) and inner nitride/outer fluoride (c). (d) The morphology of lithium deposition. (e) CEs of Li||Cu cells by the modified Aurbach method. (f) CEs of Li||Cu cells at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 0.5 mAh cm−2.

The trend of solvation structure changes with different concentration of anions. (a) Solvation structure ratio of 2 + x and y + 0.25 electrolytes. (b) The changes in the ratios of coordination structures. (c, d) Schematic diagram of solvation structure changes as NO3 − or FSI− concentration changes.

Performance comparison and analysis of lithium metal anodes. (a) CEs of Li||Cu cells by the modified Aurbach method with y + 0.25 electrolytes. (b) Cycling performance of Li||Cu cells at 0.5 mA cm−2 to 0.5 mAh cm−2. (c) CEs of Li||Cu cells with different-formula electrolytes. (d, e) Changes in solvation structure and coordination number with varying FSI− or NO3 − concentration. (f) The ratio of NO3 − to FSI− decomposition in various electrolytes.

Characterization of lithium metal anodes and generation of SEI. Morphology of lithium deposition in (a) 1.5 + 0.25, (b) 2 + 0.25, (c) 2.5 + 0.25 electrolytes. (d) XPS spectra of SEI film of deposited Li on Cu foil in 2 + 0.25 electrolytes. (e) Depth profiles of functional groups in the SEI film formed in 2 + 0.25 electrolyte. (f-i) 3D reconstructions of the topmost 15 nm of LiF2 −，NO2 −, Li−, C2H− of the SEI film formed in 2 + 0.25 electrolyte.

The performance of Li metal full cells. Voltage-capacity curve for the initial 200 cycles with (a) 1.5 + 0.25, (b) 2 + 0.5, (c) 2 + 0.25 electrolytes. (d) Long-term cycling performance of LFP||Li cells with different-formula electrolytes (N/P = 3). (e) The comparison of CEs in ether solvents by Aurbach method in previous works [35–45].

head.ce:title: Reversing nitride/fluoride distribution in the solid electrolyte interphase enables a highly reversible lithium metal anode

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A robust solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is essential for constructing high-performance lithium-metal battery (LMB). Here, we designed a unique layered SEI film with a reverse gradient distribution of nitride and fluoride compounds using a dual-salt electrolyte. Notably, the solvation structures, especially aggregates (AGG) are influenced by both the concentration effect and the binding energy differences between different anions and lithium ions. Through finely adjusting AGG, the anion decomposition processes can be controlled, thereby optimizing the component ratio of SEI film. As a result, the optimized electrolyte achieves a high CE of 99.50 % and ensures dendrite-free lithium deposition. The LMB (50 μm Li|| LiFePO4, N/P ratio is 3) achieves high capacity retention rate of 90 % after 300 cycles. This work not only develops a novel and excellent electrolyte for stable LMBs, but also reveals the internal mechanisms between solvation structure and SEI component/structure.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: We utilize typical dual-salt electrolytes (LiFSI + LiNO3) commonly used for Li-metal batteries as research models, through systematic orthogonal experiments and theoretical calculations to successfully realize the precise control of solvation structure and controllable design of SEI film. And the Li metal anode achieves a high Coulombic efficiency of 99.5 % and long cycle stability.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have reached their theoretical energy density limit (300 Wh kg−1) after decades of development[1–3]. However, they still cannot meet the demand for rechargeable batteries with even higher energy density in the electronics market. Among the available anode materials, lithium metal anode with a high capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and a low electrochemical potential of −3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), is the most promising choice for ultra-high specific energy secondary batteries[4–6]. However, the low Coulombic efficiency (CE), pronounced dendrite growth, and the issue of ''dead lithium'' in the lithium metal anode pose serious safety hazards for lithium metal batteries (LMBs) and result in a limited cycle life. These issues are primarily attributed to the continuous reactions between the highly reactive lithium metal anode and the electrolyte[7,8]. Constructing a robust SEI to prevent the continuous decomposition of electrolyte and suppress dendrite growth is an effective approach for optimizing the performance of a lithium metal anode.

For the lithium metal anode, SEI is formed by the deposition of electrochemically reduced decomposition products from the electrolyte. Firstly, the formation of SEI provides kinetic protection and thus prevents electrolyte decomposition by utilizing its ionic conduction while maintaining electronic insulation properties[9,10]. Secondly, the inorganic-rich SEI film can facilitate uniform ion flux and achieve homogeneous metal deposition. For example, Wang et al[11]. designed a SEI on the lithium metal anode, which contained abundant LiF, Li2O, Li3N, and LiNxOy particles, This design significantly improved the uniform deposition of lithium metal and optimized the cycling stability for LMB. Thirdly, the SEI which is abundant in organic constituents exhibits remarkable flexibility in effectively accommodating the volume changes of the lithium metal anode. Huang and his team[12] have developed a dual-layer SEI, which consists of an inner layer enriched with LiF and an outer layer enriched with lithiated polyoxymethylene. This enhancement the mechanical stability of SEI film results in prolonging the cycle life for LMB. Obviously, the performance of the lithium metal anode is intricately linked to the structure and components of SEI, with the inner layer of fluoride being the most widely used SEI at present. Therefore, tailoring the structure and components of the SEI film is the most effective way to promote the practical application of lithium metal anodes.

As we all know, the components and structure of SEI are primarily determined by the electrolyte species and its solvation structure. On the one hand, the SEI components are determined by the electrolyte species that decompose on the interphase. For example, the decomposition of ester solvents tends to generate an SEI mainly composed of alkyl lithium carboxylates[13–15], while the decomposition of anion reduction readily results in an SEI rich in inorganic constituents such as LiF, Li3N and Li2CO3 [11,16,17]. On the other hand, the decomposition sequence of electrolyte species on the Li metal surface, also known as their reduction potential, determines the structure of the SEI[18,19]. Therefore, designing an ideal SEI through electrolyte design is the most powerful strategy. Although there is no clear relationship between the solvation structure and the evolution of SEI, there are still some basic principles can be followed. One, within the solvation structure of contact ion pairs (CIP) and aggregates (AGG), anions preferentially decompose and derive to inorganic-rich SEI, thereby effectively passivating lithium metal[20]. Two, compared to CIP, AGG is more favorable for the formation of an anion-derived SEI with diverse inorganic components[21,22]. Therefore, to construct a robust inorganic-rich SEI film, the key to electrolyte design lies in promoting the participation of more anions in the primary solvation sheath of Li+. While the further precise regulation components and structure of SEI film depend on the careful design of AGG structure, theoretically.

In this study, we first proposed an ideal layered SEI structure with inner nitride and outer fluoride, and successfully realized the precise control of solvation structure and controllable design of SEI film through systematic orthogonal experiments and theoretical calculations utilizing typical dual-salt electrolytes as research models. The results have indicated that the solvation structure of dual-salt electrolyte is bidirectional adjustable, which is affected by both the concentration effect and the binding energy between different cations and anions. Based on these findings, we have determined that the suitable AGG structure can derive SEI film with ideal component ratio, achieving smooth and highly reversible Li deposition. Consequently, the optimized electrolyte resulted in the formation of a stable layered SEI with an inverse gradient distribution of nitrides and fluorides, which significantly enhanced the reversibility of Li deposition (CE = 99.50 %). When combined with a lithium iron phosphate (LFP) cathode, full-cells utilizing this electrolyte retained over 90 % of their initial capacity after 300 cycles at a rate of 1 C (N/P = 3).

ce:section.ce:section-title: SEI structure design and feasibility analysis
ce:section.ce:para: The properties of the SEI film are determined by its components. As shown in Fig. S1, solvent-derived organic SEI films exhibit low ion conductivity and poor stability, resulting in uneven lithium deposition/stripping. However, they possess the ability to withstand significant deformations[23]. LiF is a relatively ideal component of the SEI due to its high mechanical strength (64.7 GPa), which effectively prevents structural damage to SEI. Nevertheless, the LiF-rich SEI films impede rapid lithium-ion transport due to their low ion conductivity (10−9-10−14 S cm−1), which poses challenges in preventing dendrite formation and the accumulation of inactive lithium[20,24]. Conversely, Li3N-rich SEI films induce "mossy" Li deposition by facilitating high lithium-ion flux and exhibiting low resistance[25]. Evidently, different components exhibit distinct advantageous properties and complement each other. An ideal SEI film with high ion conductivity, excellent stability, and superior mechanical properties, requires a synergistic effect of organic, fluoride and nitride compounds.

Currently, the mosaic model[26,27] and the layered model[28] are the two primary models used to describe the SEI. In terms of the mosaic-type SEI, both organic and inorganic substances produced by electrolyte reduction are randomly distributed on the surface of lithium metal as depicted in Fig. 1a. This heterogeneous structure significantly influences the transport pathway of Li+ as it preferentially migrates along channels with higher rates of mobility. Due to the different migration rates among various SEI components, it is difficult to achieve uniform deposition/stripping of Li+ on the lithium metal anode, which in turn leads to the formation of lithium dendrites and dead lithium[12,29]. In contrast, in the layered SEI, the reduction products of electrolyte components are uniformly distributed on the electrode surface to form a layered structure. Generally, this structure consists of an inner layer composed of inorganic materials with low oxidation state and an outer layer composed of organic materials with high oxidation state. The dual-layer SEI can greatly improve the uniformity of lithium deposition while reducing consumption rates for active lithium and electrolytes. However, the introduction of two inorganic components (fluoride and nitride) results in two possible distribution models (Figs. 1b and 1c), leading to different SEI properties. In theory, in order to fully leverage the effect of nitride-induced uniform lithium deposition and utilize the excellent mechanical properties of LiF, an ideal SEI film should possess an inverse gradient distribution of fluorides and nitrides. Specifically, the content of nitrides decreases continuously from the inner layer to the outer layer, while that of fluorides exhibits the opposite trend. Additionally, the outermost layer is composed of organic components generated by solvent decomposition (Fig. 1c).

After determining the structure and components of the SEI, our primary objective is to regulate the electrolyte formula to obtain the target SEI structure. As previously analyzed, the distribution of SEI components is correlated with the decomposition sequence of electrolyte species. As shown in Fig. S2, according to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) and the characteristics of high-concentration electrolytes, as well as referring to the reported work[30,31], three different structural models for SEI were designed by formulating three electrolyte components, as shown in Fig. 1a-c. Moreover, the SEI films derivation process in three designed electrolytes were further validated through the reduction peaks in Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. S3). And the design concept and derivation process of electrolytes were analyzed in detail in Supplementary note1.

To verify the effect of the designed SEI film on anode performance, the deposition morphologies and anode performance were thoroughly characterized and systematically compared. As depicted in Fig. 1d1, The morphology of lithium metal deposited in the electrolyte without lithium nitrate (LiNO3) exhibited uneven growth and dendritic structures. However, the layered SEI derived in two electrolytes containing multiple anions significantly improved the deposition morphology (Fig. 1d2 and 1d3). Especially, Li deposited in the 2 m Bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) with 0.7 m LiNO3 (referred to as 2 + 0.7) in 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME)/1,3-dioxolane (DOL) electrolyte exhibited a denser and larger particle size deposition morphology. The Li-deposited/stripped CEs were observed within three different electrolytes using an improved Aurbach method[32], the CE of 2 + 0.7 (98.82 %) was significantly higher than that of 3 m LiFSI (96.84 %) and 2 m LiFSI + 0.25 m lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate (LiDFOB) + 0.25 m LiNO3 (referred to as 2 + 0.25 + 0.25) (97.95 %), achieving greater reversibility (Fig. 1e). Moreover, in long-term cycling tests conducted on Li||Cu half-cells, compared with 3 m LiFSI and 2 + 0.25 + 0.25 electrolyte, the average CE of 2 + 0.7 electrolyte was 98.35 %, which was consistent with the results of Aurbach method (Fig. 1f). Additionally, the use of Li||Li cells revealed that the SEI formed by the 2 + 0.7 electrolyte exhibited lower impedance (Fig. S4), resulting in reduced deposition overpotential (Fig. S5) and increased cut-off current density (Fig. S6). Specifically, the symmetric cell using 2 + 0.7 electrolyte had an overpotential of 40.6 mV after stabilization, which was smaller than that of the 3 m LiFSI electrolyte (59.8 mV) and the 2 + 0.25 + 0.25 electrolyte (67.6 mV), it also demonstrated better stability and lower overpotential at charge/discharge rates of 0.1 C, 0.5 C, 1 C, and 2 C, further confirming the advantage of the target-designed nitride inner layer of SEI film in enhancing performance. And the ion conductivity, lithium ion migration number (Fig. S7), nucleation impedance and charge transfer impedance (Fig. S4 and S8) were tested to eliminate the effect of electrolyte intrinsic properties on the performance of Li anode.

The above experiment demonstrated that the target SEI offered certain advantages in enhancing the stability of the lithium metal anode. However, as depicted in Fig. 1f, an unstable phenomenon was observed during long-term cycling tests of Li||Cu cells using the 2 + 0.7 electrolyte within the initial thirty cycles. The observed phenomenon could be ascribed to the high concentration of NO3 −, which not only led to its excessive decomposition but also restricted the decomposition of FSI−. Additionally, the insufficient LiF component resulted in instability of the SEI structure. Therefore, it is crucial to further regulate the AGG structure of the electrolyte to balance the proportion of nitride and fluoride in SEI, which is conducive to further obtaining excellent battery performance.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Ionic aggregate structure regulation of electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: As we all know, the solvation structure of the electrolyte is directly determined by its formulation. Unlike single-salt electrolytes, where the solvation structure is directly related to their concentration, the regulation of solvation structure in dual-salt electrolytes is more complex due to the different binding energies between different anions and Li+ (Fig. S9). Therefore, clarifying the evolution of the solvation structure of the dual-salt electrolyte as the formulation changes is a prerequisite for achieving SEI structure/component regulation. To this end, we prepared 2 m LiFSI + x LiNO3 (x = 0, 0.125, 0.25, 0.375, 0.5 m; hereinafter referred to as 2 + x) and y LiFSI + 0.25 m LiNO3 (y = 1.5, 1.75, 2.0, 2.25, 2.5 m; hereinafter referred to as y + 0.25) electrolytes to investigate the impact of electrolyte formulation on changes in solvation structure.

The solvation structures of different electrolytes were analyzed using Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S10). It can be observed that the Raman peaks in the frequency range of 680–800 cm−1 are attributed to symmetric stretching vibrations (S-N-S) of FSI− anions. The S-N-S bending vibrations of FSI− (680–780 cm−1) can be separated into four distinct modes through deconvolution: solvent separated ion pair (SSIP) (721.0 cm−1, uncoordinated FSI−), CIP (731.0 cm−1, Li+ coordinated with one FSI−), and two ionic aggregation modes (AGG-I at 743.0 cm−1 corresponding to Li+ coordinated with two FSI−, AGG-II at 755.0 cm−1 corresponding to one Li+ coordinated with more than two FSI−)[33,34]. The results indicated that as the concentration of LiFSI or LiNO3 increased, all peaks related to S-N-S symmetric stretching vibrations shifted towards higher wave numbers indicating changes in the coordination structures between anions and cations.

The change in the proportion of solvation structures was determined by calculating the peak area. When the LiFSI concentration was fixed at 2 m and the LiNO3 concentration increased from 0 to 0.5 m, the proportion of SSIP in solvation structures gradually decreased from 41.99 % to 20.12 %, while the proportions of CIP, AGG-I, and AGG-II increased to varying degrees ( Fig. 2a). When the LiNO3 concentration was fixed at 0.25 m and the LiFSI concentration increased from 1.5 m to 2.5 m, a similar trend in solvation structure change as observed in the first set of experiments was noticed (Fig. 2a), This demonstrates that an increase in either LiFSI or LiNO3 concentrations enhances ion coordination, facilitating more anions entering into solvation sheaths and resulting in an overall increase in AGG structure proportion. Obviously, the solvation structure evolution of the electrolyte first responds to its concentration effect.

To investigate the detailed mechanisms of different anions on the evolution of solvation structure in dual-salt electrolytes, we obtained the changing trends in the proportion of various solvation structures through fitting. As shown in Fig. 2b and S11, when the concentration of NO3 − increased, the increasing trend of CIP (k = 21.78) proportion was greater than that of AGG (k = 19.4), indicating that the increase in NO3 − concentration promoted the generation of more CIP structures in the electrolyte. This occurred because the strong binding energy between Li+ and NO3 − led to more Li+ coordinating with NO3 −, resulting in an increased ratio of remaining Li+ to FSI−. Furthermore, due to the same mechanism, the increasing trend of AGG-I (k = 14.0) was greater than that of AGG-II (k = 5.38), suggesting that the increase in LiNO3 tends to increase solvation structures of Li+ combined with one FSI− molecules rather than a tightly bound cation-anion structure (Fig. 2c).

However, when the NO3 − concentration was fixed at 0.25 m and the FSI− concentration was increased, its influence on growth trends of different solvation structure was opposite to what was observed above. Specifically, the overall proportion increase trend of AGG structure (k = 14.2) became more prominent compared to the CIP proportion increase trend (k = 3.52). Moreover, within the AGG structure, the growth rate of AGG-II (k = 8.93) was faster compared to that of AGG-I (k = 5.28), indicating that an increased concentration of FSI− played a more significant role in increasing the overall proportion of AGG-II structures and promoting more FSI− to enter the main solvation structure of Li+(Fig. 2d). Obviously, NO3 −, which has a strong binding energy with Li+, exerts a more pronounced regulatory effect on the solvation structure. The analysis of the radial distribution function (RDF) data (Fig. S12-13) demonstrates that the first peak of Li-O (NO3 −) is closer to 0 than that of Li-O (FSI−), suggesting stronger coordination between NO3 − and Li+. In both y + 0.25 and 2 +x electrolytes, anions dominated the main solvation structure. However, the coordination numbers exhibit different variation trends with the increase of the FSI− and NO3 − concentrations, respectively. These findings not only confirm the significant influence of anion concentration on the solvation structure but also align well with the experimental observations.

To verify the reliability of the above conclusion, Fig. S14 and S15 provide additional explanatory data for LiNO3 at a concentration of 0.5 m. On the one hand, with the increase in total concentration, the proportion of CIP and AGG (AGG-I, II) further increased. On the other hand, it once again confirmed that changes in FSI− concentration have a greater impact on altering the proportions within the AGG structure compared to CIP structures, with AGG-II being more affected than AGG-I.

Based on this analysis, we have clarified that FSI− and NO3 − have distinct effects on the proportion and structure of AGG (Fig. 2c, d). The regulation of solvation structure in a dual-salt electrolyte involves adjusting concentrations as well as leveraging the strong binding force provided by NO3 −. In other words, the promotion of anion entry into the primary solvation sheath to derive inorganic-rich SEI can be achieved by adding any salt, while precise regulation of the AGG structure is required to control the components of the SEI film, the latter can be achieved by coordinating the concentrations of NO3 − and FSI−.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Li-metal anode performance and its intrinsic relationship with AGG structure
ce:section.ce:para: Further, the regulatory effect of AGG solvation structure on SEI components can be evaluated by the CE. An improved Aurbach method was employed to evaluate the CE of Li deposition and stripping in Li||Cu cells. As shown in Fig. 3a, when the concentration of LiNO3 was 0.25 m and the concentration of FSI− was increased, the CEs were 97.05 %, 99.02 %, 99.50 %, 99.27 % and 99.24 %, respectively. When the fixed LiFSI concentration was 2 m and NO3 − concentration was increased, the CEs were 98.39 %, 99.23 %, 99.50 %, 98.93 % and 98.68 %, respectively (Fig. S16). It could be seen that the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte had the highest CE among all tested samples. Furthermore, long-term cycling stability of electrolytes in Li||Cu cells was also tested. The results in Fig. 3b and Fig. S17 demonstrated that initial CE (ICE) values for electrolytes with concentrations of 1.5 + 0.25 (74.94 %), 2.5 + 0.25 (72.89 %), 2 (75.5 %), and 2 + 0.5 (51.47 %) were all lower than that of the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte (78.82 %). In the electrolyte of 2 m LiFSI without adding LiNO3, voltage fluctuations occurred after only 60 cycles. Similarly, the voltage fluctuations appeared after approximately 150 cycles when adding 0.5 m LiNO3 into the electrolyte solution. Both of them can be attributed to unstable SEI formation and uneven Li deposition after prolonged cycling periods. In contrast, the utilization of y + 0.25 electrolyte exhibited increased CE, with both 1.5 + 0.25 and 2.5 + 0.25 exhibiting stable cycling for over 300 cycles, while 2 + 0.25 maintained a high average CE (97.2 %) for more than 700 cycles, aligning well with the results of the improved Aurbach method. The long-term cycling test of the symmetrical batteries (0.5 mA cm−2, 0.5 mAh cm−2) revealed significant differences in electrolyte performance (Fig. S18). The 2 + 0.5 and 1.5 + 0.25 electrolytes demonstrated relatively shorter cycle lives, experiencing short circuits after 747 h and 248 h, respectively. In contrast, Li||Li battery with 2 + 0.25 electrolyte exhibited better performance, maintaining stable cycling for over 1270 h. These results demonstrate that the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte has excellent compatibility with Li metal anodes. Moreover, compared to the other samples, the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte exhibited stable lower overpotential from initial cycles onwards, indicating the fast Li ion migration (Fig. S19 and S20). These experimental findings confirmed that the optimal electrolyte ratio of 2 + 0.25 can form a stable SEI, which can play a crucial role in enhancing the stability of lithium metal anode.

In fact, the performance of lithium metal anode is directly influenced by the SEI, which in turn depends on the solvation structure. Therefore, relvealing the correlation among solvation structure, SEI formation and Li metal anode performance holds significant importance for designing stable lithium metal anode. To this end, we evaluate the properties of SEI film derived in different electrolytes, the average CEs were tested using Li||Cu cells with different x LiFSI + y LiNO3 ratios (x = 1.5, 1.75, 2.0, 2.25, 2.5 m; y = 0.125, 0.25, 0.375, 0.5 m) shown in Fig. S21. The chessboard plot (Fig. 3c) showed that the electrolyte with a concentration of 2 + 0.25 achieved a CE of 99.50 %, which was its center point, while other concentrations exhibited a radial decrease in CE, indicating that the formulation of 2 + 0.25 electrolyte was optimal.

In order to reveal the reason why the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte can achieve optimal Li metal anode compatibility, the solvation structures of the electrolytes have been analyzed in greater depth and detail, especially AGG, which played a decisive role in the formation of SEI film. Although the concentration effect led to an increase in the absolute content of AGG as the total concentration increased, it remains unclear what the relative proportion of AGG to CIP is. The latter can to some extent reflect the dynamic transition that occurs between CIP and AGG as the electrolyte formula changes. To this end, the AGG/CIP values were calculated according to Fig. 2a. As shown in Fig. 3d, the AGG/CIP values in the y + 0.25 electrolytes increased as the concentration of FSI− increased, which was a comprehensive result of both the concentration effect and the weak interaction between Li+ and FSI−. Specifically, the relatively weak binding force between Li+ and FSI− resulted in a good dissociation for the LiFSI. Meanwhile, due to the limitation of total concentration, FSI− tended to interact with multiple Li+ ions, which is the so-called AGG, particularly AGG-II. Furthermore, the molecular dynamics (MD) simulations indicated that the coordination numbers of FSI− around Li+ increased as the FSI− concentration increased, which was consistent with the experimental results. When the concentration of NO3 − was increased, the AGG/CIP values initially increased until reaching a peak at a 2 + 0.25 before decreasing again (Fig. 3e). It was suggested that during the initial stage of increasing NO3 − concentration, concentration effects still dominated following the trend where an increased anion concentration led to more AGG structures and higher coordination numbers. However, when the LiNO3 concentration exceeded 0.25 m, the strong binding interactions between Li+ and NO3 − began to play a major role, surpassing the effects of concentration. As a result of competition for coordination with FSI−, this slowed down the tendency for multiple FSI− ions to bind with one Li+, resulting in a decrease in coordination numbers. Particularly within AGG structures, the proportion of AGG-II decreased compared to AGG-I as NO3 − increased, indicating a weakening of Li+-FSI− coordination with increasing NO3 −. The MD calculation results also confirmed that the coordination number of FSI− surrounding Li+ reached its peak value in the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte. The above analysis indicates that the concentration effect and the competitive coordination relationship of different anions play a bidirectional regulatory role in the solvation structure of the dual-salt electrolyte, and the concentration ratio of 2 + 0.25 electrolyte is the critical point for the change of AGGs proportion and structure.

Theoretically, the change of AGG proportion/structure will inevitably cause changes in the reduction decomposition process of electrolyte. To verify the important role of AGG in the SEI film derivation process, the cycle voltammetry curves were analyzed in detail to reflected the reduction decomposition process of electrolyte. The change in the area of the deconvolution peaks can reflect the decomposition amounts of different components in the electrolytes. As shown in Fig. S22, on the one side, with the increase in NO3 − concentration, both the decomposition of NO3 − and FSI− have intensified due to the concentration effect. In theory, intensifying anion decomposition is beneficial to derive more inorganic components in SEI films. On the other side, by calculating the ratio of the peak area for NO3 − reduction to that of FSI− (Fig. 3f), it was observed that as the concentration of NO3 − increased, there was a change in the relative decomposition amount of NO3 − and FSI−, indicating a shift in the relative content of nitrides and fluorides in the corresponding SEI films. Obviously, it can be demonstrated that the concentration of electrolyte affects the amount of anion decomposition, and may further affect the components and structure of SEI. When the decomposition ratio of NO3 − and FSI− in the electrolyte is 0.79, the content of SEI components in the reverse gradient distribution of nitride and fluoride reaches its optimum, thus achieving the highest CE (99.50 %) and excellent stability.

ce:section.ce:section-title: SEI film structure with nitride/fluoride reverse distribution
ce:section.ce:para: The morphology of Li deposition on copper foil was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), as shown in Fig. 4a-c and S23. When the concentration of FSI− was 1.5 m, dendrite growth appeared on the surface (Fig. 4a), as the concentration increased to 2 m, both dendrites and dead Li disappeared, presenting a flat and dense morphology (Fig. 4b). However, with a further increase in concentration to 2.5 m, dendrites and uneven deposition morphology reappeared (Fig. 4c). The lithium deposition morphology achieved with a concentration ratio of 2 + 0.25 exhibited exceptional characteristics, characterized by compact and planar lithium metal deposition with minimal porosity. Similarly, as the NO3 − concentration increased, the deposition morphology of Li changed from loose and porous (x = 0.125) to dense (x = 0.25), but when the NO3 − concentration continued to increase to 0.5 m, the surface deposition became loose again (Fig. S23).

Through evaluating the CE and deposition morphology on the performance of lithium metal anode, we obtained the most outstanding performance with a 2 + 0.25 electrolyte, which can be attributed to the formation of a stable SEI with an ideal structure and balanced components. To verify the above conjecture, the components of SEI derived in the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte were characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) etching for 0 s, 50 s and 100 s. (Fig. 4d). For the C1s, with the increase of etching time, LiCO3 increases, indicating a greater reduction degree of organic solvent and an increase in internal inorganic matter. The presence of Li3N, LiNO2 and LiNxOy inside the inner SEI layer can be attributed to the decomposition of LiNO3, indicating that LiNO3 decomposed preferentially and its products were mainly distributed in the inner layer. For the F1s spectra of SEI, LiF dominated due to the easy decomposition characteristics of FSI− in CIP/AGG. The distribution of inorganic components in the SEI corresponded to the decomposition sequence of NO3 − and FSI− anions. The changes in element composition and peak distribution fitting were observed, revealing a decrease in the proportion of fluoride as the etching depth increased. However, for nitrides, their distribution pattern was opposite as the proportion gradually increased from outer to inner layers (Fig. S24). The high elemental ratio of C at the outermost layer suggested a higher content of organic compounds that contribute to improved flexibility in SEI. In addition, XPS analysis of the 2 + 0.125 electrolyte system (Fig. S25) showed that the SEI composition was similar to that of the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte, but the stratification was less pronounced than that of the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte, demonstrating that the dual-salt electrolyte can induce a reverse gradient distribution of the nitrogen-rich and fluorine-rich SEI layer within a specific concentration range.

The distribution of SEI film components formed in the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte was also characterized by time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS). TOF-SIMS depth profile analysis (Fig. 4e) reveals that the outer SEI layer is primarily composed of organic components. The components of the inorganic layer present a gradient distribution with depth. The fluoride species decrease gradually from the outer to the inner region, while nitride species demonstrate an increase in content. Fig. 4f-i provide clear evidence that fluorine and nitrogen species are predominantly localized on the lithium surface, suggesting the formation of a dense SEI layer on the lithium anode. Specifically, the LiF2 − signal intensity, represented by the color gradient, progressively decreases from the outer to the inner layer, indicating a corresponding reduction in fluoride content. Conversely, nitrogen-containing compounds, particularly NO2 − species, are less abundant on the surface and are mainly distributed in the inner SEI layer. These observations are in good agreement with the XPS results.

Based on these analyses, as we expected, the SEI film derived in the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte consisted of organic compounds at the outer layers and gradient-distributed fluorides/nitrides at the inner layers, which can effectively supress side reactions between the electrolyte and lithium metal anode, thereby reducing electrolyte consumption and reversible Li metal inventory, while also improving the dynamics of lithium metal deposition process (Fig. S26) and regulating the deposition behavior of Li+ at the interface.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compatibility of optimized electrolyte with full-cells
ce:section.ce:para: To further demonstrate the excellent compatibility between 2 + 0.25 electrolyte and Li metal anode, a Li metal full cell was constructed by pairing a thin lithium foil (50 μm thick) with an LFP cathode with the N/P ratio of 3. During the initial 200 cycles, the cell using 1.5 + 0.25 electrolyte rapidly decayed, maintaining its original capacity of 48.32 % ( Fig. 5a), while the cell using 2 + 0.5 electrolyte maintained 85.47 % (Fig. 5b). However, the full cell using 2 + 0.25 electrolyte was cycling with stable polarization potential and almost no capacity attenuation for 200 cycles (Fig. 5c). Furthermore, it achieved excellent cycle stability after 300 cycles at 1 C with an initial capacity retention rate of 90 % (Fig. 5d).

The battery with the electrolyte ratio of 2 + 0.25 has excellent performance. And according to reported data, obviously, in the category of dual-salt electrolyte systems, even when compared to localized high concentration electrolytes, the Li metal anode in the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte exhibits the best reversibility and is among the top performers (Fig. 5e). In conclusion, in the design of SEI film through electrolyte engineering, in addition to the concentration effect, it is also crucial to carefully regulate the AGG structure based on differences in interaction between various anions and cations, especially for constructing an ideal SEI film with reasonable structure and component content in a purpose-oriented way.

In this study, we focused on optimizing the structure and components of the SEI film for Li metal anode, designed an unusual SEI film with inner nitride layer and outer fluoride layer by designing dual-salt electrolyte (LiFSI + LiNO3). Additionally, we achieved the proportion regulation of SEI components by adjusting the solvation structure, particularly AGG. The results indicate that the solvation structure of a dual-salt electrolyte is determined by both concentration effects and differences in the anion-cation interactions. In particular, as the concentration of FSI− increased, the proportion of AGG continuously increased due to the concentration effect, resulting in an increase in Li+-FSI− coordination. However, with the increasing NO3 − concentration, the concentration effect only played a major role in the initial stage. After this stage, the strong binding interaction between NO3 − and Li+ actually reduced the coordination number between Li+ and FSI−. The evolution of the AGG structure also resulted in differences in the decomposition amounts of different anions in the electrolyte, ultimately achieving optimization of the components and structure for SEI films. Therefore, by further adjusting the electrolyte formula, smooth and dense Li deposition can be achieved in the 2 + 0.25 electrolyte, exhibiting an ultra-high CE of 99.50 %. Additionally, the full cell (50 μm Li||LFP, N/P ratio is 3) achieved excellent cycling stability and retains 90 % of its initial capacity after 300 cycles at 1 C. This study elucidates the interplay among solvation structure, SEI components and lithium metal anode performance in a dual-salt electrolyte, offering a novel method for designing an ideal SEI film for Li metal batteries.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Linlin Zheng obtained her BS degree from Shandong University in 2022. She is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree at the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Nanjing University. Her research interest focuses on electrolyte design for Lithium-metal batteries and related mechanism study.

Ruilin Hou obtained his BS degree from China University of Ming and Technology in 2017, and received his PhD from the Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, University of Chinese Academy of Science in 2022. He is currently a postdoctoral researcher at the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Nanjing University. His research interest focuses on electrolyte design for advanced secondary batteries and related mechanism study.

Tianze Shi obtained his BS degree from Northwest University in 2019, and received his MS degree from the Chongqing Institute of Green and Intelligent Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Science in 2022. He is currently a Ph.D. student at School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University. His research interest focuses on electrolyte design for sodium-metal batteries and related mechanism study.

Xinyi Sun received her B.E. degree from Soochow University in 2019 and obtained her Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering at Nanjing University in 2024. Her major research interests focus on structural and component design of metal−air batteries.

Aoyuan Chen obtained his BS degree from Wuhan University of Technology in 2022. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree at the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Nanjing University. His research interest focuses on lithium metal anode for advanced secondary batteries and related mechanism study.

Haoshen Zhou obtained his BS degree from Nanjing University in 1985, and received his PhD from the University of Tokyo in 1994. He is a professor in the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Nanjing University. His research interests include the synthesis of energy active materials and their applications in Li-ion batteries, Na-ion batteries, Li-redox flow batteries, metal–air batteries, and new type batteries/cells.

Shaohua Guo received his PhD from the University of Tsukuba in 2015, after which he worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST). He is currently a Professor at the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Nanjing University, and a researcher in Shenzhen Research Institute of Nanjing University. His research interest involves energy materials and chemistries for advanced secondary batteries.
